text.p: These are the leading stories in the Turkish press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
SABAH

- Deputy prime minister Tansu Ciller has entered a dangerous bargain with her Islam-based Welfare Party coalition partners, by agreeing to block a prosecution threatening to close Welfare on condition that she receive the premiership.
MILLIYET
- A meeting of senior officials from the D-8 group of Moslem countries agrees to strenthen cultural ties.
HURRIYET
- Conservative tourism minister, Bahattin Yucel will resign from his ministry in opposition to the continued coalition with Welfare.

- Islamist Welfare will submit a declaration of a three-way coalition to include a small far-right party to President Suleyman Demirel and demand the appointment of Ciller as caretaker prime minister.
YENI YUZYIL
- Islamist Prime Minister Necmattin Erbakan secretly opens religious high schools while the army are demanding their closure.
- The head of the state-owned electricity producer, TEAS, has halted production in three power plants in western Turkey without explanation, angering the local businessmen.
- Turkish and British officails agree on cooperating against drug abuse and traficking.
RADIKAL
- Ciller accuses the Turkish military of trying to frighten her party's deputies into withdrawing from the coalition government.
- Parliament passes a law legalising trade unions for civil servants.
DUNYA
- Private Turkish bank, Sumerbank buys a bank in Germany.
- Ceylan Holding invest $1 billion to build a textile factory in northern Turkey in a joint venture with Japanese and American companies.
ZAMAN
- A Turkish young businessmen's organisation unveiled a report on the effects of elections on the economy.
- A report on Turkey's problem-ridden Social Security Authority reveals that it serves 43 percent of the population.
CUMHURIYET
- University deans call for the implementation of a military-inspired secularist education plan to extend compulsory schooling to eight years in order to bloc early religious education.
